title: Introduction
text: vignette illustrate basic use case simulated dataset dat1 part package. dataset illustrates measurements latent response variable. variables id: identifier study subjects. item: identifier one three items measure underlying latent trait interest. y: measurement given item. x: predictor variable. plot shows measurements item.

title: Introduction
text: Letting \(y_{ij}\) denotes \(\)th measurement \(j\)th subject, assume measurement part \[y_{ij} = \beta_{0} + \eta_{j} \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T} \boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij}  + \epsilon_{ij}\] \(\boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij}\) vector whose \(k\)th element equals 1 \(\)th measurement \(j\)th subject measurement item \(k\), \(\boldsymbol{\lambda} = (1, \lambda_{2}, \lambda_{3})^{T}\) vector factor loadings, whose first element set 1 identifiability. Furthermore, \(\eta_{j}\) denotes latent variable subject \(j\), assumed identical across three items, \(\epsilon_{ij} \sim N(0, \sigma^{2})\) residual term. Next, structural part relates latent variables predictor variables, \[\eta_{j} = f(x_{j}) + \zeta_{j}\] \(x_{j}\) predictor variable subject \(j\) vary within subjects, \(\zeta_{j} \sim N(0, \psi)\) disturbance term (random intercept). Plugging structural model measurement model yields reduced form \[y_{ij} = \beta_{0} + f(x_{j}) \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T} \boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij} + \zeta_{j} \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T} \boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij}  + \epsilon_{ij}\] fixed values \(\boldsymbol{\lambda}\), reduced form defines generalized additive mixed model (GAMM) (Wood 2017) varying coefficient term \(f(x_{j}) \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T} \boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij}\) random effect term \(\zeta_{j} \boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T} \boldsymbol{\delta}_{ij}\). Identifying lets us use profile likelihood estimation similar Jeon Rabe-Hesketh (2012) proposed subset GLLAMMs, Rockwood Jeon (2019) implemented R package PLmixed. current implementation galamm uses profile likelihood algorithm, extended smooth nonlinear functions.

title: Introduction
text: start defining loading matrix, using syntax PLmixed. NA means loading free estimated, whereas value means fix corresponding loading. fit model. set initial values lambda_init = c(2, .4) speed convergence example case. initial values provided, random starting points used instead. NB! model set set identified \(\lambda\) equal, since term s(x, = weight) also contains constant component. problem can fixed using mixed model representation described vignette maximum likelihood estimation.
code: load.mat <- matrix(c(1, NA, NA), ncol = 1) dimnames(load.mat) <- list(c("item1", "item2", "item3"), NULL) load.mat #>       [,1] #> item1    1 #> item2   NA #> item3   NA mod <- galamm(   formula = y ~ s(x, by = weight),   random = ~(0 + weight|id),   data = dat1,   load_var = "item",   lambda = load.mat,   factor = "weight",   lambda_init = c(2, .4)   )

code: library(PLmixed) data("IRTsim") IRTsub <- IRTsim[IRTsim$item < 4, ] set.seed(12345) IRTsub <- IRTsub[sample(nrow(IRTsub), 300), ] IRTsub <- IRTsub[order(IRTsub$item), ] irt.lam = c(1, NA, NA)

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
text: can use marginal_likelihood function galamm compute marginal likelihood model given values fixed effects \(\beta\), variance components \(\theta\), factor loadings \(\lambda\). start adding \(\lambda\) variable model: generate components linear mixed model: fixed effects matrix contain factor loadings, keep . random effects matrix contain factor loadings, need mapping. Zt compressed sparse column format, diff(Zt@p) thus shows us number entries column transposed matrix. also extract random effects covariance matrix, mapping \(\theta\). See Bates et al. (2015) details. can now start confirming able compute likelihood model. marginal_likelihood function returns log-likelihood, can compare PLmixed: marginal_likelihood function also returns gradient marginal likelihood respect \(\theta\), \(\beta\), \(\lambda\), order. Reassuringly, close zero. however PLmixed returns maximum profile likelihood, albeit consistent, maximum likelihood estimate (Gong Samaniego 1981; Parke 1986; Pawitan 2001). gradient computed algorithmic differentiation using autodiff C++ library (Leal 2018), means exact computer precision. can use gradient find maximum likelihood estimates model (technically, Laplace approximate marginal maximum likelihood estimates). also use memoise avoid evaluating function unnecessarily. start optimization pretty arbitrary values, converges quite fast, solution identical one PLmixed found. set fnscale = -1 get negative log-likelihood, optim minimizes. can confirm parameters identical:  also clear reader PLmixed much convenient use. However, optimization shown faster. practice, useful test different values lmm argument, defines many iterations L-BFGS-B algorithm keep memory approximating Hessian. inverse negative Hessian matrix covariance matrix model. can obtain one single call final parameter estimates, using argument hessian = TRUE. can confirm also standard errors agree PLmixed. \(\hat{\beta}\) \(\hat{\lambda}\).

rep(dat$item, each = 2) - 2L Lambdat <- lmod$reTrms$Lambdat theta_mapping <- lmod$reTrms$Lind - 1L ml <- marginal_likelihood(   y = dat$y,   trials = rep(1, length(dat$y)),   X = X,   Zt = Zt,   Lambdat = Lambdat,   beta = fixef(irt.model),   theta = getME(irt.model$lme4, "theta"),   theta_mapping = theta_mapping,   lambda = irt.model$Lambda[[1]][, "abil.sid", drop = TRUE][2:3],   lambda_mapping_X = integer(),   lambda_mapping_Zt = lambda_mapping_Zt,   weights = numeric(),   weights_mapping = integer(),   family = "gaussian",   family_mapping = rep(0L, nrow(dat)),   maxit_conditional_modes = 1 ) irt.model$`Log-Likelihood` #> [1] -193.5633 ml$logLik #> [1] -193.5633 ml$gradient #> [1] -1.219268e-06 -1.959015e-06  3.175238e-13  1.398881e-13  4.058975e-13 #> [6] -2.035351e-05  1.550563e-05 library(memoise) theta_inds <- 1:2 beta_inds <- 3:5 lambda_inds <- 6:7 bounds <- c(0, 0, rep(-Inf, 5))  mlwrapper <- function(par){   marginal_likelihood(     y = dat$y,     trials = rep(1, length(dat$y)),     X = X,     Zt = Zt,     Lambdat = Lambdat,     beta = par[beta_inds],     theta = par[theta_inds],     theta_mapping = theta_mapping,     lambda = par[lambda_inds],     lambda_mapping_X = integer(),     lambda_mapping_Zt = lambda_mapping_Zt,     weights = numeric(),     weights_mapping = integer(),     family = "gaussian",     family_mapping = rep(0L, nrow(dat)),     maxit_conditional_modes = 1     ) }  mlmem <- memoise(mlwrapper) fn <- function(par){   mlmem(par)$logLik } gr <- function(par){   mlmem(par)$gradient } par_init <- c(1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 1) opt <- optim(par_init, fn = fn, gr = gr,               method = "L-BFGS-B", lower = bounds,              control = list(fnscale = -1))  opt$value #> [1] -193.5633 irt.model$`Log-Likelihood` #> [1] -193.5633 plot(   opt$par,    c(getME(irt.model$lme4, "theta"), fixef(irt.model),      irt.model$Lambda[[1]][2:3, 1]),   xlab = "optim()", ylab = "PLmixed"); code: glmod <- glFormula(cbind(incidence, size - incidence) ~ period + (1 | herd),                    data = cbpp, family = binomial) devfun <- do.call(mkGlmerDevfun, glmod) opt1 <- optimizeGlmer(devfun) devfun <- updateGlmerDevfun(devfun, glmod$reTrms) opt2 <- optimizeGlmer(devfun, stage=2) fMod <- mkMerMod(environment(devfun), opt2, glmod$reTrms, fr = glmod$fr) theta_inds <- 1 beta_inds <- 2:5  mlwrapper <- function(par, hessian = FALSE){   marginal_likelihood(     y = cbpp$incidence,     trials = cbpp$size,     X = glmod$X,     Zt = glmod$reTrms$Zt,     Lambdat = glmod$reTrms$Lambdat,     beta = par[beta_inds],     theta = par[theta_inds],     theta_mapping = glmod$reTrms$Lind - 1L,     family = "binomial",     maxit_conditional_modes = 50,     hessian = hessian   ) }  mlmem <- memoise(mlwrapper) fn <- function(par){   mlmem(par)$logLik } gr <- function(par){   mlmem(par)$gradient }  set.seed(123) opt <- optim(   par = c(1, runif(4)), fn = fn,    method = "L-BFGS-B", lower = c(0, rep(-Inf, 4)),   control = list(fnscale = -1, maxit = 2000, lmm = 20) ) final_model <- mlwrapper(opt$par, hessian = TRUE) final_model$logLik #> [1] -92.02628 logLik(fMod) #> 'log Lik.' -92.02657 (df=5) fn(opt2$par) #> [1] -92.02629 sqrt(diag(solve(-final_model$hessian)))[beta_inds] #> [1] 0.2324714 0.3066424 0.3266377 0.4274364 unname(sqrt(diag(vcov(fMod)))) #> [1] 0.2312140 0.3031506 0.3228302 0.4220492

title: Generalized Additive Latent and Mixed Models
text: galamm R package fitting multivariate generalized additive mixed models factor structures. package currently development, changes API must expected. package uses interface similar PLmixed, fits generalized linear mixed models factor structures. However, galamm allows semiparametric estimations gamm4, hence flexibly allows estimation nonlinear effects. don’t need semiparametric estimation, hand, use definitely PLmixed, much mature package. plan package provide tool fast scalable estimation generalized linear latent mixed models (GLLAMMs) (Rabe-Hesketh, Skrondal, Pickles 2004) semiparametric extensions termed generalized additive latent mixed models (GALAMMs) (Sørensen, Fjell, Walhovd 2021). already possible extent, using function marginal_likelihood, documented vignette maximum likelihood estimation. obtain , combine sparse matrix computations RcppEigen (Bates Eddelbuettel 2013) automatic differentiation using C++ library autodiff (Leal 2018).
